translated: Khuddaka-pāṭha
The Discourse on the Householder Tirokudda
They stand in the inner rooms,
and in the doorways and doorjams;
They stand in the door-lintels,
having come to their own home.
When there’s plenty of food and drink,
and snacks and meals are laid out,
No one remembers them,
because of the deeds of beings.
Thus they give to their relatives,
those who are compassionate,
pure, excellent, timely,
suitable food and drink.
“May this be for your relatives,
may your relatives be happy;
And they, having come together there,
the relatives who have died, gathered together,
when there’s plenty of food and drink,
they rejoice with appreciation;
“May our relatives live long,
for whose sake we receive (this).
And we have made an offering,
and the donors are not without fruit.
For there is no agriculture there,
and cattle-rearing is not found there.
There is no such trade there,
where one can buy and sell with money;
From here they are sustained there,
the relatives who have died,🔽Just as when the rain falls on the mountains,
it flows down to the lowlands,
Just so, what is given here
Benefits the departed.
Just as the full rivers
Fill up the ocean,
Just so, what is given here
Benefits the departed.
‘He gave to me, he did for me,
He was a relative, friend, or intimate;
One should give an offering for the departed,
Remembering what they did in the past.

original: Na hi ruṇṇaṁ vā soko vā,🔽yā caññā paridevanā;
analyzed: na hi ruṇṇam vā sokaḥ vā  yā caññā paridevanā
translated: For neither weeping nor sorrow
Nor any other kind of mourning🔽Will benefit the departed:
In this way relatives stand by.
But this offering given
Is well established in the Sangha;
It will benefit them for a long time,
It will help them in the right place.

analyzed: so ñāti dhammaḥ ca ayam nidassito
translated: This is the way of relatives shown,
And a great worship of the departed is done;
Strength is given to the monks,
